title: Otakar Kraus
text:
Otakar Kraus (10 December 1909 — 28 July 1980) was a <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czech</a> (later <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a>), <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="baritone">baritone</a> and teacher.
He was born in <a href="Prague">Prague</a> and studied there with Konrad Wallerstein and in <a href="Milan">Milan</a> with Fernando Carpi. He himself was the teacher of a number of important British <a href="Bass%20%28vocal%20range%29">bass</a>es, including <a href="Robert%20Lloyd%20%28singer%29">Robert Lloyd</a>, <a href="Willard%20White">Willard White</a>, <a href="John%20Tomlinson%20%28singer%29">John Tomlinson</a>, <a href="Gwynne%20Howell">Gwynne Howell</a> and Colin Iveson. He taught the British Baritone John Rawnsley and he was also a teacher of New Zealand baritone <a href="Barry%20Mora">Barry Mora</a>.
He made his operatic debut as Amonasro in "<a href="Aida">Aida</a>" in <a href="Brno">Brno</a> in 1935. From 1936 to 1939 he sang as principal baritone at the <a href="Slovak%20National%20Theatre">Slovak National Theatre</a> in <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a>. In 1940, he moved to England, appearing at the <a href="Savoy%20Theatre">Savoy Theatre</a> in <a href="Modest%20Mussorgsky">Mussorgsky</a>'s "<a href="The%20Fair%20at%20Sorochyntsi">The Fair at Sorochyntsi</a>", and from 1943 to 1946 he appeared with the <a href="Carl%20Rosa%20Opera%20Company">Carl Rosa Opera Company</a>, singing Scarpia, Germont, the three roles in Hoffmann and other parts. After seasons with the <a href="English%20Opera%20Group">English Opera Group</a> and the <a href="De%20Nederlandse%20Opera">Netherlands Opera</a>, he joined the <a href="Royal%20Opera%20House">Royal Opera House</a>, <a href="Covent%20Garden">Covent Garden</a> in 1951, and sang there until 1973.
Kraus specialised in villainous characters. His roles at Covent Garden and worldwide included Don Pizarro in "<a href="Fidelio">Fidelio</a>", Iago in "<a href="Otello">Otello</a>" and Scarpia in "<a href="Tosca">Tosca</a>", as well as Alberich in the "<a href="Der%20Ring%20des%20Nibelungen">Ring cycle</a>" at the <a href="Bayreuth%20Festival">Bayreuth Festival</a> from 1960 to 1962. He created the roles of Nick Shadow in <a href="Igor%20Stravinsky">Stravinsky</a>'s "<a href="The%20Rake%27s%20Progress">The Rake's Progress</a>", Tarquinius in <a href="Benjamin%20Britten">Britten</a>'s "<a href="The%20Rape%20of%20Lucretia%20%28opera%29">The Rape of Lucretia</a>", King Fisher in <a href="Michael%20Tippett">Michael Tippett</a>'s "<a href="The%20Midsummer%20Marriage">The Midsummer Marriage</a>", Diomede in <a href="William%20Walton">Walton</a>'s "<a href="Troilus%20and%20Cressida%20%28opera%29">Troilus and Cressida</a>", and the Sheriff in <a href="Gian%20Carlo%20Menotti">Gian Carlo Menotti</a>'s "<a href="Martin%27s%20Lie">Martin's Lie</a>".
He died in <a href="London">London</a>.
The <a href="Otakar%20Kraus%20Music%20Trust">Otakar Kraus Music Trust</a>, a charity which provides <a href="music%20therapy">music therapy</a> to children and adults with special needs,
was founded by Dr. Margaret Lobo, a former pupil, in memory of him.
It was founded in 1988 in <a href="Twickenham">Twickenham</a>, London and now operates in that local area and also in <a href="The_Music_Therapy_Trust">India</a>.
His name is mentioned in the Czech film "Cosy Dens" (1999) by Jirí Kodet (as Kraus).
